subNodes.conversationText: The young witch heard a creak from within the woods. Pharaoh cried out. Looking into the trees, the young witch could just see an ominous mass against the lighter shadows of the boughs around it. Squinting, <he/she> could discern what it was: from a long, thick tree limb hung a body.
The head hung low over a noose's loop. A stool lay toppled over on the ground beneath.

<He/She> stood close enough to see and to smell the figure more distinctly now. It was a woman, but decay made it hard to tell what kind of woman she'd been. She wore no jewelry, and her clothes were very plain. A small scroll was tied around her wrist with a black thread.
<FirstName> untied the thread and unrolled the scroll.

"To the One Who Finds Me,

"Do not wonder about my little life. I had my troubles, and they are over now. Do not look for my friends or family: I have none. Just cut the rope and set me on the forest floor, away from the eyes of men.

"A Suicide."
<He/She> gave way to tears. After a time they passed.
Then <he/she> wondered -- What should <he/she> do with the body?

With a thud, the body fell to the ground. <FirstName> dragged it into some underbrush about ten feet deeper into the woods, where there were dead leaves and foliage sufficient to cover it. Then <he/she> destroyed the stool and removed the rest of the noose from the tree, hiding both with the corpse. Knott stood sentinel, and Pharaoh, very curious about the body, hopped about <FirstName>'s feet as <he/she> worked.
Witches do not pray for the dead, but <FirstName> said a few kind words before leaving the body alone.

As <he/she> returned to the path, <he/she> heard voices and laughter coming the opposite direction. Knott instantly became a normal gourd. Two men approached, both about the same age, lightly armed and plainly dressed. They stopped short when they saw <FirstName>.
"Traveler!" one of them said. "A woman came into these woods some time ago. Have you seen anyone?" He went on to describe the woman <FirstName> had so recently cut from the limb.
"Who are you, and why are you looking for this woman?"
The men exchanged glances. The same one spoke again.

"I'm her brother, and this is my good friend. My sister vanished more than a week ago without any word to anyone. We were afraid she'd come into the woods -- this place has a bad reputation."

considered the man's account and weighed it against the note 'd found.
"Then you haven't seen her?" He peered intently at <FirstName>.
"I have seen her, but she wishes to remain unseen. I respect her wishes."
"We need to know where she is."
"Tell us. Now." The man's companion, hitherto silent, spoke in a low, gruff voice. His hand went to the hilt of a sword at his waist. "What has she told you? Who are you?"
"I'm a servant of the Wooden Crone. A witch. Don't threaten me."
The two men went ashen and took a step back.
"I told you there were witches here. Probably why she came," said the first man.
Before the young witch could do anything else, they fled.
"It doesn't matter. The woman you're looking for doesn't want to be found."
As soon as the weapon was in the man's hand, Knott appeared. He towered over the men, strange, grim, and silent. They stared, aghast. The sword dropped to the ground.
"Me? No one. She told me nothing. There's no need to get angry. I'll help you."
<FirstName> went on to describe how <he/she>'d found the corpse. <He/She> showed them the note and took them to the place where <he/she>'d concealed the body.
"I'm sorry. You're too late. I do indeed know where your sister is."
<FirstName> went on to describe how <he/she>'d found the corpse. <He/She> showed them the note and took them to the place where <he/she>'d concealed the body.
"Yes, but I'm afraid she met a bad end."
<FirstName> went on to describe how <he/she>'d found the corpse. <He/She> showed them the note and took them to the place where <he/she>'d concealed the body.

The men stared.

"There she is. There she is indeed." They seemed surprised but not, thought, very sad.
"After all that," the second man said. He shook his head in wonder.

The first man gave the second a warning look.

"Thank you, traveler," he said to the young witch. "I -- I do wish this had ended differently."
The second man grunted his assent.
"Not likely," the young witch said to <him/her>self, wondering if <he/she>'d done the right thing.
<He/She> left the two men and the corpse behind.
<He/She> left the two men and the corpse behind.
"No. Not many people travel these woods."
Witches do not pray for the dead. <His/Her> work done, <he/she> left the body alone.

As <he/she> returned to the path, <he/she> heard voices and laughter coming the opposite direction. Knott instantly became a normal gourd. Two men approached, both about the same age, lightly armed and plainly dressed. They stopped short when they saw <FirstName>.
<He/She> left it there and went <his/her> way.
"Sad creature!" <FirstName> thought to <him/her>self. "Not everyone is fit for this life."
Then <he/she> wondered -- What should <he/she> do with the body?
A fox leapt into the path. It turned to glance at <FirstName> and Knott, pranced in a circle, and then darted into some underbrush.
[Folk Magic] It is well known that a fox crossing one's path is a good omen.
Some even say that the animal leads travelers to buried treasure, hidden places, and other secrets.
It looked to <FirstName> as if the fox wanted <him/her> to follow. So <he/she> did.
But <FirstName> did not have time to verify these legends. <He/She> hurried on.
It looked to <FirstName> as if the fox wanted <him/her> to follow. So <he/she> did.

The fox scampered merrily through the woods while followed. The first part of the chase led through fern brakes and over mossy slopes. Pharaoh swooped and dived overhead, and Knott crashed bull-like behind. [10 minutes pass.]
But now <FirstName> grew tired of what would likely be a fruitless pursuit.
The fox led the witch and companions down into a valley. The air was cooler there and the green very dark. They passed over a brook with water as black as ink. [10 minutes pass.]
But now <FirstName> grew tired of what would likely be a fruitless pursuit.
And still the chase went on.

After crossing the brook, they began climbing again. If the fox hadn't slowed down, would have been unable to follow: the ascent was too steep, and a thick, thick fog had suddenly, unnaturally settled over the region. The fox was barely a red ghost ahead of . [Ten minutes pass.]
The young witch began to grow uneasy. It was time to turn back.
Ten more minutes passed in the fog. The fox vanished. Even Knott and Pharaoh were invisible now.
But then <FirstName> heard Pharaoh's familiar squawk. The young witch followed the sound and found the bird sitting on Knott's head. The fog, meanwhile, had begun to lift.
<He/She> stood in a clearing. Around <him/her> lay implements of war. Two forces had clashed here long ago, it seemed. The weapons were brittle and useless, the armor even worse.

In the middle of the battlefield stood a heap of bones. Strips of moldering flags hung from it like the banners off a castle, some blue, some red, though both had faded so much that the distinction seemed inconsequential.
The witch imagined the sturdy flesh that had covered these bones, the fresh silks, the forgotten names...
<He/She> smiled to <him/her>self as if stirred by a fond memory.
After an hour's search, <he/she> found <his/her> way back to the path.

Then the fox stepped out from behind the pile, ran up to <FirstName>, and circled <his/her> legs again. It ran off into the woods, and the young witch realized that <he/she> stood exactly where <he/she> had stood before following it. There was no clearing, no fog, no bones.
<He/She> heard the fox's laugher in the distance.
"Stupid fox!" <he/she> said to <him/her>self. "What do I want with an old pile of bones?"
After an hour's search, <he/she> found <his/her> way back to the path.
This was too much. The young witch turned away.
After an hour's search, <he/she> found <his/her> way back to the path.
[Folk Magic] It is well known that a fox crossing one's path is a good omen.
Some even say that the animal leads travelers to buried treasure, hidden places, and other secrets.
[Folk Magic] It is well known that a fox crossing one's path is a good omen.
Some even say that the animal leads travelers to buried treasure, hidden places, and other secrets.
[Folk Magic] It is well known that a fox crossing one's path is a good omen.
Some even say that the animal leads travelers to buried treasure, hidden places, and other secrets.
[Folk Magic] It is well known that a fox crossing one's path is a good omen.
Some even say that the animal leads travelers to buried treasure, hidden places, and other secrets.
An owl hooted in the gloom. Far off, another owl answered. Knott stopped walking. Interpreting this as a warning, the young witch did too.
A minute passed, still and silent.
"Come along, Knott. I hope you're not afraid of owls."
The witch started walking, but Knott didn't budge. Had something gone wrong with Eldest Lady's spell?

Then <FirstName> heard something off the path to the left: it was breaking the twigs, disturbing the fallen leaves. But it was not a footstep, and it didn't sound like an animal, either -- at least no animal <FirstName> knew. It sounded like something being dragged, or like a plow with no plowman. It stopped and started again. It was getting closer.
The young witch quickened <his/her> pace, hoping Knott would move now.
He did. Pharaoh flew after them. Whatever made the noise did not follow.

The dragging noise got closer and closer to the left edge of the path. Then <FirstName> heard it, too, on the opposite side -- the same dragging noise, the same disturbance of leaves and wood, the same nearness.
The young witch ran, hoping Knott would follow.
He did. Pharaoh flew after them. Whatever made the noise did not follow.
Then there was a third dragging sound, this time behind <him/her>.
The young witch went into the woods to investigate the noises.
As soon as <he/she> stepped off the path, <he/she> could see nothing. The darkness was thicker than expected. An unplaceable voice spoke to <him/her>.

"Keep your wits about you, witch. The three
Of us are dragging corpses to the feast-halls. 
Don't cross our paths if you don't want to come."
The young witch ran, hoping Knott would follow.
The young witch marched boldly into the woods to investigate the noise that sounded closest.
As soon as <he/she> stepped off the path, <he/she> could see nothing. The darkness was thicker than expected. An unplaceable voice spoke to <him/her>.
The young witch marched boldly into the woods.
As soon as <he/she> stepped off the path, <he/she> could see nothing. The darkness was thicker than expected. An unplaceable voice spoke to <him/her>.

"Keep your wits about you, witch. The three
Of us are dragging corpses to the feast-halls. 
Don't cross our paths if you don't want to come."
"What are you? Where are you? I can't see anything."

"We are the waiters of the crone, the Bound Ones.
All who see us perish, all who touch us
Die. Stay clear, stay clear. A glance or graze
Will kill you."
The Bound Ones! <He/She> fought off terror. Where were they?
Getting closer, from the sound of it.

It was hard to see where to go. The dragging sounds seemed to come from all around. The witch felt suddenly turned around and couldn't even tell where the path lay. <He/She> neither heard nor saw anything of Knott or Pharaoh.

"Not as you see things, but well enough
To mark you now."
"Then go around me. I do not wish to die."

"Neither look at us nor tremble overmuch
As we go by, lest shaking make your flesh
Touch ours.
The young witch's hair stood on end as a corpse slid out of the gloom. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. <He/She> closed <his/her> eyes.
The young witch's hair stood on end as a corpse slid out of the gloom. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. <He/She> closed <his/her> eyes.

It was hard to see where to go. The dragging sounds seemed to come from all around. The witch felt suddenly turned around and couldn't even tell where the path lay. <He/She> neither heard nor saw anything of Knott or Pharaoh.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

Invisible? No. Inconceivably, it was there, visible now. Bound One, Bound One... Waiter at the crone's table. One of the ones who raised the goblet to her mouth and cut the clay to serve the children, one of the ones who swept bones into the ancient sea.

It had a bird's head but no eyes. It had the body of a very old man. With each step, foul-smelling liquid ran down its legs, but from perforations in its beak came steam and a rich aroma of spiced meat.
"You've seen us and must die," said the Bound One.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it, but at the last moment, recalling what the thing had said, <he/she> averted <his/her> eyes.
The noises passed. The young witch stumbled back to the path.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

"You've seen us and must die," said the Bound One.

"You've seen us and must die," said the Bound One.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it, but at the last moment, recalling what the thing had said, <he/she> averted <his/her> eyes.
The noises passed. The young witch stumbled back to the path.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

Bound One, Bound One. Waiter at the Crone's table. It raised the goblet to her mouth and cut the clay to serve the children. It swept bones into the ancient sea.

It had a bird's head but no eyes.

It had the body of a very old man.

With each step, foul-smelling liquid ran down its legs, but from holes in its beak came steam and a rich aroma of spiced meat.
It turned its head. "I see you. Time to go."

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it.

<His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it, but at the last moment, recalling what the thing had said, <he/she> averted <his/her> eyes.
The noises passed. The young witch stumbled back to the path.
"Can you see me?" <he/she> called out to the beings.

"Not as you see things, but well enough
To mark you now."

So <he/she> didn't. <His/Her> hair stood on end. Through the gloom of the forest floor slid a corpse. It was lashed to something invisible and was being dragged like a canoe. Instinctively, the young witch's eyes searched for the invisible being that led it, but at the last moment, recalling what the thing had said, <he/she> averted <his/her> eyes.
Still the young witch waited, listening.
The witch started walking, but Knott didn't budge. Had something gone wrong with Eldest Lady's spell?
The young witch heard something nearby.
A rustle, then a chirp -- a dark fluttering, and then the thing -- bird, beast, or something else -- was gone.
A deer sprang onto the path, looked at Knott and the young witch, and then sprang into the brush on the other side.
The noise stopped, and <he/she> continued on <his/her> way.
<He/She> heard it again, but further away now. Whatever creature made it was moving on.
Voices! But whose, and from where? They were very faint and soon hardly discernible.
Perhaps it had just been the wind in the trees.
